location: An ante-chamber of the QUEEN'S apartments.

lines.text: Enter ANNE and an Old Lady

lines.speaker: anne
lines.text: Not for that neither: here's the pang that pinches: His highness having lived so long with her, and she So good a lady that no tongue could ever Pronounce dishonour of her; by my life, She never knew harm-doing: O, now, after So many courses of the sun enthroned, Still growing in a majesty and pomp, the which To leave a thousand-fold more bitter than 'Tis sweet at first to acquire,--after this process, To give her the avaunt! it is a pity Would move a monster.

lines.speaker: old lady
lines.text: Hearts of most hard temper Melt and lament for her.

lines.speaker: anne
lines.text: O, God's will! much better She ne'er had known pomp: though't be temporal, Yet, if that quarrel, fortune, do divorce It from the bearer, 'tis a sufferance panging As soul and body's severing.

lines.speaker: old lady
lines.text: Alas, poor lady! She's a stranger now again.

lines.speaker: anne
lines.text: So much the more Must pity drop upon her. Verily, I swear, 'tis better to be lowly born, And range with humble livers in content, Than to be perk'd up in a glistering grief, And wear a golden sorrow.

lines.speaker: old lady
lines.text: Our content Is our best having.

lines.speaker: anne
lines.text: By my troth and maidenhead, I would not be a queen.

lines.speaker: old lady
lines.text: Beshrew me, I would, And venture maidenhead for't; and so would you, For all this spice of your hypocrisy: You, that have so fair parts of woman on you, Have too a woman's heart; which ever yet Affected eminence, wealth, sovereignty; Which, to say sooth, are blessings; and which gifts, Saving your mincing, the capacity Of your soft cheveril conscience would receive, If you might please to stretch it.

lines.speaker: anne
lines.text: Nay, good troth.

lines.speaker: old lady
lines.text: Yes, troth, and troth; you would not be a queen?

lines.speaker: anne
lines.text: No, not for all the riches under heaven. Old Lady: 'Tis strange: a three-pence bow'd would hire me, Old as I am, to queen it: but, I pray you, What think you of a duchess? have you limbs To bear that load of title? No, in truth.

lines.speaker: old lady
lines.text: Then you are weakly made: pluck off a little; I would not be a young count in your way, For more than blushing comes to: if your back Cannot vouchsafe this burthen,'tis too weak Ever to get a boy.

lines.speaker: anne
lines.text: How you do talk! I swear again, I would not be a queen For all the world.

lines.speaker: old lady
lines.text: In faith, for little England You'ld venture an emballing: I myself Would for Carnarvonshire, although there long'd No more to the crown but that. Lo, who comes here?
Enter Chamberlain

lines.speaker: chamberlain
lines.text: Good morrow, ladies. What were't worth to know The secret of your conference?

lines.speaker: anne
lines.text: My good lord, Not your demand; it values not your asking: Our mistress' sorrows we were pitying.

lines.speaker: chamberlain
lines.text: It was a gentle business, and becoming The action of good women: there is hope All will be well.

lines.speaker: anne
lines.text: Now, I pray God, amen!

lines.speaker: chamberlain
lines.text: You bear a gentle mind, and heavenly blessings Follow such creatures. That you may, fair lady, Perceive I speak sincerely, and high note's Ta'en of your many virtues, the king's majesty Commends his good opinion of you, and Does purpose honour to you no less flowing Than Marchioness of Pembroke: to which title A thousand pound a year, annual support, Out of his grace he adds.

lines.speaker: anne
lines.text: I do not know What kind of my obedience I should tender; More than my all is nothing: nor my prayers Are not words duly hallow'd, nor my wishes More worth than empty vanities; yet prayers and wishes Are all I can return. Beseech your lordship, Vouchsafe to speak my thanks and my obedience, As from a blushing handmaid, to his highness; Whose health and royalty I pray for.

lines.speaker: chamberlain
lines.text: Lady, I shall not fail to approve the fair conceit The king hath of you. I have perused her well; Beauty and honour in her are so mingled That they have caught the king: and who knows yet But from this lady may proceed a gem To lighten all this isle? I'll to the king, And say I spoke with you.
Aside
Exit Chamberlain

lines.speaker: anne
lines.text: My honour'd lord.

lines.speaker: old lady
lines.text: Why, this it is; see, see! I have been begging sixteen years in court, Am yet a courtier beggarly, nor could Come pat betwixt too early and too late For any suit of pounds; and you, O fate! A very fresh-fish here--fie, fie, fie upon This compell'd fortune!--have your mouth fill'd up Before you open it.

lines.speaker: anne
lines.text: This is strange to me.

lines.speaker: old lady
lines.text: How tastes it? is it bitter? forty pence, no. There was a lady once, 'tis an old story, That would not be a queen, that would she not, For all the mud in Egypt: have you heard it?

lines.speaker: anne
lines.text: Come, you are pleasant.

lines.speaker: old lady
lines.text: With your theme, I could O'ermount the lark. The Marchioness of Pembroke! A thousand pounds a year for pure respect! No other obligation! By my life, That promises moe thousands: honour's train Is longer than his foreskirt. By this time I know your back will bear a duchess: say, Are you not stronger than you were?

lines.speaker: anne
lines.text: Good lady, Make yourself mirth with your particular fancy, And leave me out on't. Would I had no being, If this salute my blood a jot: it faints me, To think what follows. The queen is comfortless, and we forgetful In our long absence: pray, do not deliver What here you've heard to her.

lines.speaker: old lady
lines.text: What do you think me?
Exeunt
